body:
Jacoco does not support report aggregation. So if you want to create a single coveralls report for your multimodule project, use Cobertura instead. There are some hacks that allow creating aggregate reports, but I think it's not worth the trouble.

To enable cobertura and report aggregation, add the following to your parent module's pom:

``` xml
      <plugin>
        <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
        <artifactId>cobertura-maven-plugin</artifactId>
        <version>2.5.2</version>
        <configuration>
          <format>xml</format>
          <maxmem>256m</maxmem>
          <aggregate>true</aggregate>
        </configuration>
      </plugin>
      <plugin>
        <groupId>org.eluder.coveralls</groupId>
        <artifactId>coveralls-maven-plugin</artifactId>
        <version>2.0.0</version>
      </plugin>
```

If you are not using Travis CI, remember to provide repository token for the coveralls maven plugin, with Travis CI you can omit the token.

And to create the aggregate report, then run in the parent module:

```
mvn clean cobertura:cobertura coveralls:cobertura
```

You can test how the report generation goes by supplying `-DdryRun=true` parameter for the maven command.

And for Travis CI, add the following to your `travis.yml`:

```
after_success:
  - mvn clean cobertura:cobertura coveralls:cobertura
```

Thank you for the quick response.  I am one step closer, but still not there.  Now I am getting an authentication error:

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.eluder.coveralls:coveralls-maven-plugin:2.0.0:cobertura (default-cli) on project glusterfs-java-filesystem-project: IO operation failed: peer not authenticated -> [Help 1]

Full log: https://travis-ci.org/semiosis/glusterfs-java-filesystem/builds/10298655

Any help would be much appreciated.  Thank you!

If I set the coveralls URL to use HTTP instead of HTTPS then I get past the peer authentication error and i get a null pointer exception:

Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: charset
        at java.io.InputStreamReader.<init>(InputStreamReader.java:115)
        at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.httpclient.CoverallsClient.parseResponse(CoverallsClient.java:87)
        at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.httpclient.CoverallsClient.submit(CoverallsClient.java:81)
        at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.AbstractCoverallsMojo.submitData(AbstractCoverallsMojo.java:289)
        at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.AbstractCoverallsMojo.execute(AbstractCoverallsMojo.java:173)
        ... 21 more

I tried this on my local machine instead of travis.  I did add my repoToken to the config when I ran on my machine.

...[later]...

Ok never mind this comment.  I captured the traffic and I see that using HTTP only causes coveralls to redirect to HTTPS.  That explains the NPE.

So now the question is back to why does HTTPS cause the peer authentication error.

I think there's an issue with OpenJDKs default trusted certificates and the certificate coveralls.io uses. I just forked your repo, made it Travis and Coveralls enabled and did few tests. First i ran with your current config and got the same peer not authenticated error which is caused by issuing an SSL connection without a trusted certificate in keystore.

After that i changed Travis to use oraclejdk7 but got a failing test in `GlusterFileSystemProviderTest.java`. Not sure if this was due to change of the JDK, but I just ignored it to get along. After ignoring the test the coverage report was submitted right.

This issue is unfortunate, because the certificate mismatch will not allow any openjdk7 users in Travis to submit coverage reports to Coveralls. You could try to use Oracle JDKs keystore somehow when running the build or add the Coveralls certificate to Travis env keystore in before install phase. Or I could roll a version of the plugin that ignores the certificate validity, but I would not want to do this because it is a security risk and could allow a man in the middle attack.
I've contacted to Travis and Coveralls about this issue. Hopefully they'll be in touch soon so we can find a solution.
Thanks, thats good to hear.  I'm looking forward to getting this running on my projects.

issue.title: "peer not authenticated" for OpenJDK 7 under TravisCI

repository.name: coveralls-maven-plugin
repository.description: Maven plugin for submitting Java code coverage reports to Coveralls web service.

issue.body:
I noticed you've already encountered this issue, mentioned in the comments in #15 ([relevant comment](https://github.com/trautonen/coveralls-maven-plugin/issues/15#issuecomment-22822094)). I've also encountered the issue, so I think it could probably use its own discussion thread.

See [here](https://travis-ci.org/eloquent/lockbox-java/jobs/11119809#L1346) for another build failure example.

Is this something that can be worked around by running a command of some sort before execution?

body:
After some thorough tests I found that the issue is not actually with the certificate, but with the OpenJDK itself. Seems that OpenJDK does not properly support Elliptic Curves according to this [bug report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/openjdk-6/+bug/1006776). The workaround is to disable the PKCS provider totally.

Adding the following command to before_install phase in Travis solves the problem:

```
sudo sed -i 's/security.provider.9/#security.provider.9/g' $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/java.security
```

A complete working openjdk7 Travis configuration with the Coveralls plugin can be found at https://github.com/trautonen/jersey-mustache/blob/master/.travis.yml.
Thanks, was able to get it working with this fix.

Hey guys, looks like Codeship has exactly the same issue. I reached out to them to see if they can fix it (I obviously cannot execute any sudo commands before my maven command.. :( 

Travis worked for me too. So no biggie.

issue.title: "peer not authenticated" for Codeship

repository.name: coveralls-maven-plugin
repository.description: Maven plugin for submitting Java code coverage reports to Coveralls web service.

issue.body:
Hello, 

Codeship seems to have the same error with their OpenJDK. (Similar issue as https://github.com/trautonen/coveralls-maven-plugin/issues/15#issuecomment-24030323)

There doesn't seem to be any options to select a different JDK nor can I disable the PKCS provider since their interface does not allow sudo commands.

They are currently looking into the issue are are wondering if using OpenJDK8 would fix this problem.

body: This should be resolved in 2.0.1 version.

issue.title: Provide failOnError attribute

repository.name: coveralls-maven-plugin
repository.description: Maven plugin for submitting Java code coverage reports to Coveralls web service.

issue.body:
Hi there,
I have the following project:
- parent
  - module1
  - module2
  - module3

and I have configured the maven surefire AND failsafe plugins to produce results in each of the module's target folder. So to run the build I run the following in the parent folder:

> mvn clean install coveralls:report -Ptest 

which cleans (with success), builds(with success), executes tests(with success), generates jacoco reports(with success) in each module and then it starts executing the coveralls:report but it fails because parent has no source, no tests and hence no jacoco.xml so the coveralls plugin complains with the following:

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.eluder.coveralls:coveralls-maven-plugin:3.0.1:report (default-cli) on project platform: I/O operation failed: No coverage report files found -> [Help 1]

here's the stacktrace:
Caused by: java.io.IOException: No coverage report files found
    at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.util.CoverageParsersFactory.createParsers(CoverageParsersFactory.java:101)
    at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.CoverallsReportMojo.createCoverageParsers(CoverallsReportMojo.java:231)
    at org.eluder.coveralls.maven.plugin.CoverallsReportMojo.execute(CoverallsReportMojo.java:196)

I'd like to have an attribute like 'failOnError' maybe which can be set to true or false. This way if jacoco.xml was not found the build will continue to the next modules instead of failing.
